This work, for the first time, highlights that small-sized graphite crystallite and highly defective carbon-based catalysts can effectively increase the −SO3H density of the catalysts and modulate the surface electronic properties of the catalysts, which further facilitates the α-pinene hydration reaction. Hydrothermal phosphoric acid modulation of graphite crystallite size and defects in carbon-based catalysts systematically revealed the correlation between −SO3H density, catalytic activity, graphite crystallite size, and defects in biomass carbon. The characterization results demonstrate that small-size graphite crystallites and high structural defects provide more sp2 hybridized carbon edges, contributing to the catalyst's increase of −SO3H density. The −SO3H group density of the catalyst increased from 0.89 to 1.20 mmol/g after hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment. The catalyst has the highest efficiency in the α-pinene hydration to α-terpineol among the reported catalysts, in which 87.06 % of α-pinene was converted and reached a maximum α-terpineol selectivity (55.38 %) time only 22 h. Density functional theory calculations show that the lattice defects of graphite crystallites in catalysts lead to the polarization of the electron cloud around the catalyst, which further leads to the reduction of electrostatic resistance between α-pinene and the active catalytic sites. The apparent activation energy of hydration by the catalyst is 1.74 times lower than that of conventional biomass carbon-based solid acids. The reduction of graphite crystallite size is considered a critical step in improving the selectivity of α-terpineol attributed to the effective reduction of α-terpineol adsorbed on the catalyst. Introduction As one of the largest sources of bio-oil, worldwide turpentine oil production is estimated at approximately 35,000 tons/year. This turpentine mainly comprises monoterpenes, of which α-pinene accounts for the most significant proportion. The above bio-oil sources oils offer an up-and-coming alternate platform and a greener route to fulfilling the increasing demand for alternative relevant daily life and energy resources. Therefore, these terpenes have been extensively used in industry, agriculture, and potentially as a fuel additive [1]. As renewable feedstock, α-pinene is a raw material for multifunctional organic compounds, perfumery, and fine value-added chemicals. In the presence of an acidic or basic catalyst, α-pinene generates lobes, camphene, anethole, and borneol by ring expansion or p-menthanes and α-terpineol by opening the four-carbon ring. Among them, α-terpineol, the primary and most important commercial product of the monoterpene alcohol fraction, is prepared by the hydration of α-pinene, one of the 30 commonly used fragrance compounds. α-Terpineol is a monocyclic tertiary alcohol structure. It exists in natural plants and has the structural formula C10H18O. The α-terpineol was one of the earliest synthetic fragrances and has been industrially produced with a history of more than 100 years. Besides, it is one of the bulk fragrance products, which covers a wide range of fragrance products, with an annual output of several thousand tons worldwide. The α-terpineol is widely used in industry, agriculture, and medicine. The synthesis of α-terpineol helps increase the added value of turpentine and promotes forestry economic sustainable development. The synthetic industrial route of α-terpineol is mainly a “two-step method” with 30 % diluted H2SO4, which catalyzed turpentine to synthesize terpineol hydrate and then dehydration with dilute acid to produce α-terpineol [1–3]. However, some drawbacks still exist in the industrial synthesis of α-terpineol, such as separation of products, equipment corrosion, long production period, and low product yields, which are serious problems. The effluent liquor and residuum in the process should be minimized to achieve more efficient and clean production of α-terpineol. The practical solution is to introduce a solid acid catalyst. The most common heterogeneous solid acid catalysts are zeolite, ion exchange resin, molecular sieve, membrane material, etc. [4–6]. The investigation by Sekerová [7] involved the preparation of montmorillonite K10, which was treated by H2SO4 and used in the hydration of α-pinene. And 60 % conversion of α-pinene was achieved with 45 % selectivity to α-terpineol. Compared with liquid Brönsted acid catalysts, solid acids have received extensive attention due to their high catalytic activity, easy recovery, and reusability. In addition, replacing homogeneous catalysts with heterogeneous catalysts is becoming increasingly important in the chemical and life science industries. Among the available literature reports, the amount of Brönsted acid, the strength of acidity, and the solid acid of catalyst porosity greatly influence the α-pinene hydration reaction activity and the selectivity of α-terpineol [5–7]. Although the solid acid catalysts have made stage progress in the hydration reaction of α-pinene, the catalytic performance of the solid acid catalysts is yet to be improved based on the present results. Therefore, further improvement of the selectivity of α-terpinol is considered one of the main challenges. In addition, the effect of other properties in the catalyst on the catalytic performance should also be of interest relative to the conventional physicochemical properties mentioned above, such as the size of graphite crystallites (acidic catalytic site hosting sites) and structural defects in biomass carbon-based solid acids. Ironically, the effect of graphite crystallite size and defects in biomass carbon on the hydration of α-pinene to prepare α-terpineol has not been investigated. Production of value-added chemicals from renewable carbon resources is increasingly critical to a more sustainable economy. Recently, owing to a high degree of surface reactivity, large surface areas, and chemical stability, biomass carbon-based materials have been applied in the fields of adsorbent, electrode materials, ideal catalyst supports, or sensitive gas-detecting materials. Furthermore, biomass carbon-based solid acid catalysts (CACs) are emerging as promising materials capable of catalyzing esterification, dehydration, hydrolysis, and hydration reactions [8–11]. However, the uses of CACs are limited in practical applications due to the low density of acidic catalytic sites [12,13]. In general, many aliphatic alkyl side chains in the biomass carbon (sp3 hybrid carbon) hinder the loading of −SO3H groups, which are only attached to the edges of the graphite crystals (sp2 hybrid carbon). We previously reported that carbon-based solid acid catalysts with 0.8 mmol/g of −SO3H density were synthesized from rice straw via the classical carbonization-sulfonation method [14]. Moreover, Table S1 exhibits the total acidity and −SO3H density of CACs reported in other literature. Unfortunately, compared with CACs, sulfoacid resin from commercial exhibited higher −SO3H density (4.7 mmol/g). Consequently, further increased −SO3H density of CACs is seen as one of the main challenges. The most effective method to regulate the surface physicochemical properties of carbon materials is well known to be doping the carbon matrix with heteroatoms, such as nitrogen, oxygen, and phosphorus [15–17]. As a typical doping atom, the phosphorus atom (P) can significantly regulate the defects and electron properties of carbon materials due to its outermost lone pair of electrons and larger atomic diameter, which has been extensive and in-depth research [18]. Many studies have focused on the ability of electron donor-acceptor of heteroatoms on carbon materials for the effect of catalytic performance. The conjugation of the aromatics π-bonds (i.e., graphite crystallite) of carbon materials and the lone-pair electrons of P can further distort the carbon structure, resulting in defects and available active sites. Recently, Guo et al. reported the preparation of phosphorus-functionalized CNTs (PCNTs) by direct hydrothermal treatment of carbon nanotubes (CNTs)-H3PO4 mixtures at 170 °C. The phosphorus content of PCNTs was high, 1.66at %. In addition, hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment could effectively etch the –CH2– a group of the edge of the CNTs in the temperature at 170 °C [19]. To the best of our knowledge, the effects of structural defects caused by heteroatoms on the −SO3H active centres of CACs have never been explored. In addition, the effects of graphite crystallite size and structural defects in CACs on the hydration reaction of α-pinene are yet to be revealed. Rice is grown around the world, including in Northern America, Asia, Europe, and Latin America [20–22]. However, the massive production of rice translates to the excessive production of rice straw, which is generally dumped and burned off, thus causing underutilization. The rice straw has abundant catheters and vascular bundles, implying a well-developed pore structure in the rice straw. Therefore, rice straw is a promising host material for preparing CACs. It is widely known that doping the carbon matrix with heteroatoms has become promising materials capable of catalyzing reactions such as electrochemistry, hydrogen evolution, oxygen evolution reaction, etc. [23–25]. However, the effects of structural defects caused by heteroatoms and the removal of aliphatic alkyl side chains on the −SO3H active centres of carbon-based solid acid have never been explored. In addition, to our knowledge, there are no publications on synthesizing CACs with high density −SO3H active centres (>1 mmol/g) via hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment biomass carbon. Firstly, it should be noted that to the best of our knowledge, it is proposed for the first time that small-sized graphite crystallite and structural defects are beneficial for increasing the −SO3H density of carbon-based catalysts (CACs) in this study. Second, reports on CACs to date have been limited to focusing only on the effects of the amount of Brönsted acid, acidity, and catalyst porosity on the selective conversion of α-pinene hydration to α-terpineol. Ironically, the effect of graphite crystallite size and defects on catalytic performance has not been studied. In this study, the synergistic effect of graphite crystallite size and defects on the hydration reaction is revealed for the first time by combining adsorption experiments and density functional theory calculations. In conclusion, the present study provides a feasible route to further increase the −SO3H density of CACs and to improve their catalytic performance in hydration reactions (increased selectivity of α-terpineol). Furthermore, it was demonstrated that modulation of graphite crystallite size and defects in CAC can stimulate its interesting acid catalytic properties and potential applications. In the current literature, the effect of the size and defects of graphite crystallites of CACs on the catalytic reaction had never been explored, especially for the application of α-pinene hydration for the preparation of α-terpineol. Here, for the characteristics of CAC materials, we developed a hydrothermal phosphoric acid pretreatment method to improve the catalytic properties of the materials. The results showed that the hydrothermal phosphoric acid pretreatment method could effectively regulate the graphite crystallite size and defects in the CACs. The increase in the −SO3H density of the catalysts to 1.2 mmol/g was attributed to the small-sized graphite crystallites and high defects rather than the pore structure, as demonstrated mainly through characterization by X-ray diffractometer (XRD), Raman and acid-base titration. Subsequently, the efficiency of the novel carbon-based solid acid catalysts (RSCA-HP2) in the hydration reaction with pinene was tested, and the optimal operating conditions for the process were determined to provide the highest yield of α-terpineol. Finally, a combination of adsorption experiments and density functional theory (DFT) clarified that small-sized graphite crystallites were the key to improving the selectivity of α-terpineol. The high degree of defects was able to facilitate the contact between α-pinene molecules and −SO3H by modulating the electronic properties of the catalysts, thus facilitating the hydration reaction to take place. In addition, the high density −SO3H and deformed graphite crystallites in the RSCA-HP2 were able to provide superior stability to it, and the catalysts still maintained good catalytic activity after 66 h of reaction. Materials and methods Material α-Pinene (98 % purity), concentrated H2SO4 (98 %), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), acetone (CH3COCH3), and alcohol (CH3CH2OH) were of analytical grade purchased from Macklin Chemical Reagent Factory (Shanghai, China). In September 2022, the experimental field of Guangxi University in Nanning, China, provided this study with the same planting lot of rice straw (RS). The Rice straw was collected by manual harvesting. The Rice straws were washed through ultrasonic concussion and then dried at 105 °C for 8 h before vacuum storage. Catalyst preparation Biomass carbon-based solid acid catalysts with a high acidity were prepared by sulfonating the biomass carbon after hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment. In detail, the length of the rice straw was cut to <1 cm. The cut rice straw was transferred to a beaker containing 500 mL of deionized water and ultrasonically washed for 2 h to remove the dirt from the surface of the straw. The sample at the end of ultrasonication was filtered and dried at 105 °C for 12 h. The above-washed rice straw was ground and sieved (40 mesh) using a mixer mill to obtain powdered rice straw (RS). The carbonization procedure of the carbon precursors was as follows: 5 g of RS was heated from 30 to 300 °C at a flow rate of 80 ml/min of N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C/ min. The temperature of the furnace was maintained at 300 °C for 2 h. The obtained powder was denoted as RSC, where ‘C’ is the carbonized biomass. The RSC was routinely transferred to 50 ml of ethanol to remove the tar produced during the carbonization process. The above sample was then immersed in 50 ml of 0.01 mol/L dilute HCl and ultrasonic for 12 h to remove excess metal oxides (e.g., iron, magnesium, aluminum, etc.) from the RSC. This was filtered to remove the excess acid solution. Similarly, the sample was transferred to containing 50 ml of 0.01 mol/L NaOH stirred at 80 °C for 12 h with the aim of removing excess silica from the RSC. The purified biomass carbon (RSC) was thus obtained. The 11.7 mol/L of H3PO4 (50 mL) and RSC (1 g) were well mixed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a volume of 60 ml. The H3PO4/RSC mixture was sealed and maintained at 180 °C for 10 h. The samples were further washed with deionized water to neutral and then dried at 105 °C for 8 h. The hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment biomass carbon prepared with 8.78, 10.24, 11.70, 13.16, and 14.63 mol/L phosphoric acids were defined as RSCHP, RSCHP1, RSCHP2, RSCHP3, and RSCHP4, respectively. The powder mentioned above (1 g) was further treated with 20 mL of sulfuric acid under a reflux system at 80 °C for 3 h. The filtered paste was washed with 80 °C distilled water until pH = 7 and dried for 8 h at 105 °C. The obtained sample was denoted as RSCA-HP, RSCA-HP1, RSCA-HP2, RSCA-HP3, and RSCA-HP4. Investigatment of catalytic activity The α-pinene hydration reaction was carried out in a 100 mL round-bottom flask with condensing tubes under constant stirring. Typically, 4.3 g of α-pinene, 5.25 g of deionized water, a certain amount of catalyst (0.4∼0.6), and 20 mL of solvent (acetone) were added to the flask and heated to the required reaction temperature (60∼100 °C) in an oil bath for a period of time (18∼24 h) with 300 rpm stirring. Finally, the concentration of α-pinene and α-terpineol in the remaining product from the above reaction mixture was measured by a Shimadzu gas chromatograph (GC). Results and discussion Characterization Trace element analysis Biomass substrates are known to contain a large number of trace impurities such as iron, nitrogen, calcium and silicon. The main objective of this study was to investigate the effect of graphite crystallite size and defects in biomass substrates on the −SO3H density and catalytic performance of CACs. Based on this, the RSCs were purified in this study using dilute hydrochloric acid and sodium hydroxide to reduce the effect of trace impurities on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the XPS spectra of unpurified RSC as well as purified samples (RSC, RSC700, RSC700-P, and RSCHP). The intensity of the O 1 s peak of the purified samples decreased significantly relative to that of the unpurified RSC. Notably, no Ca 2p diffraction peaks were found in the purified samples, which is favourable for the α-pinene hydration reaction, attributed to the fact that the α-pinene hydration reaction is a classical Brönsted acid-catalyzed reaction. The semi-quantitative results of surface elements for all samples are shown in Table 1 . As expected, Ca species were removed from the purified samples. In addition, the absence of N species on the surface of the samples prepared at high temperatures (RSC700 and RSC700-P) can be observed. Compared with the unpurified RSC, the N content in RSC and RSCHP2 obtained by preparation at low temperature was reduced to 2.81 and 2.76 wt %, respectively. According to Advani et al., it was shown that some of the N species inherited an alkaline nature, which is unfavorable for the hydration reaction [1]. The slight increase in the content of Si species in the purified samples could be attributed to the exposure of Si inside the carbon-based material during the purification process. According to Balan et al., it was shown that Si can act as a support for C porous structures and that −SO3H groups do not anchor to the surface of Si species [26]. Based on this, it is reasonable to assume that trace Si species will not adversely affect the main thrust of this study. In summary, the purification step is effective in removing alkaline impurities that adversely affect the catalytic performance of CACs. In addition, the presence of trace Si species does not negatively affect the main idea of this work. Surface morphology The morphology of all the precursors and catalysts was studied by using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Fig. 3 (a)–(h)). As shown in Fig. 3(a)–(c), the RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 displayed a piping structure with a rough outer surface. In addition, the inner surface structure of RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 differed from the outer surface. The inner wall of RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 was supported by porous inner layers and channel structure. From Fig. 3(a)-(c), the internal orifice diameter of samples (RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2) ranged from 19 µm to 92 µm. According to the literature, larger pores (>1 µm) were called voids to avoid confusion [26]. Thus, it could be seen that a large number of voids were presented in the RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 from the SEM images (Fig. 3(d)). In addition, after phosphoric acid immersion and high-temperature carbonization, a coralloid pellet can be observed on the external wall surface of RSC700-P. The above phenomenon might be due to the disintegration of rice straw (RS) caused by the heat treatment from phosphoric acid chemical activation. As shown in Fig. 3(e)–(f), the SEM images reveal that the prepared catalysts possess similar morphologies and structures corresponding to catalyst precursors, which might be attributed to the difficulty of effectively improving the morphologies of a catalyst via low-temperature sulfonation process. Fig. S1(a)–(h) shows energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) images of all the samples. The main components of all the catalyst precursors were the C element and the O element in EDS measurement. In addition, for the RSC700-P and RSCHP2, as displayed in Fig. S1(c)–(d), besides the element of carbon and oxygen, the element of phosphorus was also discovered. These results indicated that the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment introduced a small amount of P atom to biomass carbon (i.e., RSCHP2). In addition, the surface elemental composition of all the catalysts was performed via EDS (Fig. S1). As displayed in Fig. S1(e), (f), and (h), except for the elements of C and O, the elements of S were also discovered in the EDS images of the RSCA, RSCA700, and RSCA-HP2, which means −SO3H groups had successfully introduced to the carbon layer as a result of H2SO4 treatment. However, compared with the RSCA700, the elements of S were non-existent in the RSCA700-P (Fig. S1(g)), indicating that the dope of P was an adverse effect on the progress of sulfonation. This phenomenon could be attributed to a large number of P-dope enhancing lattice stability of catalyst precursors [18], further resulting in −SO3H groups being difficulty linked to the carbon layer. However, the elements of S were observed in the EDS images of RSCA-HP2. In addition, after the sulfonation treatment, it is noteworthy that the component of P atoms in the RSCA-HP2 even disappeared completely. This implied that it was unstable extremely nature that phosphorus species in the RSCHP2 were obtained via a hydrothermal phosphoric acid process. Pore structure The N2 adsorption-desorption curve and pore size distribution of the catalyst precursors prepared in this work were further researched by N2 adsorption-desorption tests. The N2-adsorption and desorption isotherms and pore distribution of the catalyst precursors are shown in Fig. 4(a)–(b). It could be seen from Fig. 4(a) that the isotherms of RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 relate to type III according to the IUPAC classification, indicating that samples were characteristic of non-porous or macropore materials. According to the analytical result of the SEM, the inner wall of RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 had abundant voids which reached the micron scale. Therefore, it could be inferred that the prepared catalyst precursors were macropore materials via hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment and carbonization. In fact, according to Lyu et al. research, the N2-adsorption desorption curves of a series of SiO2-based solid acid catalysts exhibit type III and type IV isotherms, respectively. This is attributed to the differences in the pore structure of the catalysts due to the different preparation processes [27]. In addition, the report also clearly indicated that the FT-IR spectra of silica substrates showed typical bands related to the formation of condensed siloxane networks evident at the fingerprint region (Si-O band vibrations of about 960, 798, and 457 cm−1). Chen et al. similarly reported that the silica SBA-15 contained the classical type IV isotherm. Based on this, the N2 -adsorption-desorption curves (type III isotherms) of RSC and RSCHP2 in this study have similarities with some silica [28]. However, it should be emphasized that the FT-IR spectra in this study show almost no characteristic absorption bands on silica in the fingerprint region below 1000 cm−1 (See Section 3.1.4.). In addition, the reason why the vast majority of samples exhibit type III isotherms is attributed to the fact that RS contains a large number of pores (>1 µm). This observation was demonstrated in the SEM analysis. Compared with the materials with only micropores and mesopores, the N2 molecules adsorbed on the supporter with a large number of pores (RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2) are more readily desorbed from the interior of the samples, further resulting in the absence of hysteresis loops in the isotherms of the three supporters mentioned above. In addition, it was also demonstrated in the 3.1.1 section that the surface Si content of the purified samples was lower than 5 wt %. The above conclusions are sufficient to prove that the N2-sorption desorption curves of the catalysts in the present work belong to the unique N2-sorption desorption isotherms of RS-based carriers and not silica. Recently, Lin et al. reported that the N2 isotherm of a corn stover-based catalyst exhibited a type IV with a distinct H4 hysteresis return line [29]. In addition, Balan et al. developed a carbosilicate-based acid catalyst utilized for biodiesel production, and the N2 isotherm of this material was type II [30]. In summary, the evidence obtained from reports in the literature, SEM, and FT-IR is sufficient to support the view that the type III N2 isotherm of the catalysts in this study is due to the natural properties of the RS carbon supporters and/or hydrothermal phosphoric acid process factors. However, the isotherms of the RSC700-P were close to type IV ones, accompanied by a hysteresis loop [26,31]. Additionally, it could be seen from Fig. 4(b) that the mesoporous pore size of RSC700-P was mainly concentrated at 7.8 nm, 4.9 nm, and 3.5 nm (BJH method calculation), respectively. This implied that RSC700-P belonged to mesopores materials. The pore structure parameters of all catalyst precursors are summarized in Table 2 . As the carbonization temperature increased from 300 to 700 °C, the surface area and pore volume of the resultant catalyst precursors (RSC700) increased accordingly. However, the RSCHP2 prepared with the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment exhibited a small specific surface area (409.4 m2/g) and pore volume (0.24 cm3/g). Compared with RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2, it was evident that RSC700-P has the largest specific surface area (665.1 m2/g) and pore volume (0.95 cm3/g). The above-mentioned results suggested that, unlike conventional phosphoric acid activation, the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment was challenging to produce possession of the high specific surface area and pore volume of catalysts precursors. This was attributed to the fact that the used temperature of the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment technology was low (180 °C), and catalyst precursors were almost difficult to etch with phosphoric acid [32,33]. Although the porosity of RSCHP2 was slightly lower than other catalyst precursors with the present work (RAC700 and RSC700-P), the specific surface area obtained by RSCHP2 was 409.4 m2/g, which was much higher than the previously reported about biomass carbon-based solid acid [34]. Thus, the RSCHP2 could still be considered a potential carbon-based solid catalyst precursor with abundant porosity. The N2 physisorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of all catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 (c)–(d). It could be seen from Fig. 4(c)–(d) that the isotherms type and pore size distribution trend of all the catalysts were similar to the experimental results of all the catalyst precursors. Furthermore, the pore structure parameters of all catalysts were summarized in Table 2. Except for the RSC and RSCA, the pore structure parameters of catalysts corresponding to catalyst precursors were similar. Besides the RSC, the above results indicated that the pore structure of catalyst precursors was few subject to the influence of low-temperature sulfonation. Compared with the other three catalysts, the specific surface area and total pore volume of RSCA showed a significant increase after low-temperature sulfonation treatment. This phenomenon could be attributed to the RSC having many aliphatic side chains, and further partial pore cracking in the carbon precursor by glycosidic bond breakage of hemicellulose and cellulose during the sulfonation process, leading to a higher level of porosity in the catalysts [12,14]. Functional group The presented Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) in Fig. 5 (a) reflects the nature of the surface functionalities of the catalyst precursors. As shown in Fig. 5(a), several distinct vibrational modes of various types of functional groups can be easily identified in all the catalyst precursors, such as C–O–C (∼1108 cm−1), C=C (∼1411, ∼1559, and ∼1680 cm−1), –C = O (∼1712 cm−1), –CH2– (∼2881 and ∼2951 cm−1), and –OH (∼3080 and ∼3600 cm−1) [35]. In view of the characteristics of FTIR spectra mentioned above, as for the catalyst precursors, the surface functional group of all the samples were majorly composed of sp2 and sp3 hybrid carbons, and the similar types of side chains of oxygen-containing functional groups (i.e., –OH, –C = O, and –COOH). However, the relative intensity of the peaks was an obvious difference. Compared with that of RSC, the peak intensity of –CH2– of the aliphatic alkanes on the as-prepared RSCHP2 showed a small decline. Recently, Guo et al. reported that H3PO4 could effectively etch the –CH2– a group of the edge of the amorphous carbon at the temperature of 170 °C [19]. Combined with the FTIR spectra results, it was reasonable to deduce that H3PO4 also can effectively etch the –CH2– a group of aliphatic alkanes in the RSCHP2 in the case of hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C. The decreased –CH2– group of aliphatic alkanes was beneficial in producing more available edges of the carbon sheets with graphite, which would facilitate introducing more −SO3H active centres into carbon-base catalysts. Moreover, compared with other catalyst precursors, the FTIR spectra of RSC700-P show a wide absorption band at 1193–1180 cm−1, which it is preliminary to deduce that a broad absorption band includes superposition of multiple signals, such as the P=OOH, P = O, and O–C (P–O − C) functional groups [18]. However, the absorption band of the P species functional group was hardly observed in the RSCHP2, which may be attributable to the content of phosphorus species in RSCHP2 being low, and the phosphorus species content was even under the lower detection limit of FT-IR. The functional groups of all catalysts were investigated using FT-IR characterization techniques. As shown in Fig. 5(b), compared with the catalyst precursors, the vibrational band of the RSCA, RAC700, and RSCHP2 at around 1050 cm−1 was attributed to asymmetric stretching of –S = O [13], suggesting that the –SO3H group was successfully loaded on the catalyst precursors through sulfonation treatment. The asymmetric stretching of –S = O was not discovered in the FTIR spectra of RSC700-P, which was consistent with the EDS results. Elemental analysis of catalyst precursors and catalysts Although the results of FT-IR show clear proof of various types of functional groups, the existence of the superposition of multiple functional groups in the FTIR spectra is far from enough to understand specific element configurations in the samples. Therefore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the surface configuration of C, O, P and S on the surface of all samples and to further reveal the elemental content of the sample surface in a semi-quantitative manner. As shown in Fig. 6 , the XPS shows two characteristic peaks at about 532 and 284 eV, corresponding to the O 1 s and C 1 s peaks in all the samples. The P 2p peaks could only be observed in the phosphoric acid activation samples (RSC700-P, RSCA700-P, and RSCHP2), further demonstrating the successful introduction of P atoms into the RSCHP2. Furthermore, compared with catalyst precursors (Fig. 6(a)–(c)), the characteristic peaks at about 168 eV corresponding to the S 2p (Fig. 6(g)) were presented in the RSCA, RSCA700, and RSCA-HP2. The high-resolution C 1 s peaks of all the samples are deconvoluted, as shown in Figs. 6(a) and (d). Three major peaks at 284.8 eV (C=C), 286.6 eV (-C–C/CH), and 288.7 eV (C = O/–CO) appear for the catalyst precursors and catalysts [14]. Furthermore, compared with the other samples, the 290.0 eV (π–π*) also appeared for the RSC700, RSCA700, RSC700-P, and RSCA700-P. The peaks with binding energies at 531.9, 533.1 and 535.1 eV (Fig. 6(b) and (e)) are attributed to the C = O, –OH, and –O–C oxygen peaks of the samples, respectively. In addition, the high-resolution P 2p spectrum of both RSC700-P and RSCA700-P could be deconvoluted into two different peaks at 134.0 and 136.5 eV, which correspond to the CO-P and P2O5 (Fig. 6(c) and (f)), respectively [18]. In contrast, the peak at 136.5 eV (P2O5) was absent from the RSCHP2 (Fig. 6(f)). It is noteworthy that the CO-P peaks of RSCA-HP2 disappeared utterly. The semi-quantitative results for surface elements in RSC, RSC700, RSC700-P, and RSCHP2 samples are recorded in Table 3 , calculated according to the XPS area in C 1 s, O 1 s, and P 2p spectra. It should be noted that the presence of the π–π* shake-up satellite relates to the degree of cross-linking between graphite carbon sheets [23]. As shown in Table 3, the presence of the π–π* shake-up satellite in RSC700 and RSC700-P indicates larger conjugated graphitic domains in the above-mentioned catalyst precursors than in RSC and RSCHP2. Namely, the XPS areas of π–π* shake-up satellite in RSC700 and RSC700-P were 8.09 and 4.86, respectively, whereas π–π* shake-up satellite could not be observed in the RSC and RSCHP2, illustrating small-size graphite carbon sheets more easily obtain via low-temperature carbonization than high-temperature carbonization. The formation of large conjugated graphitic domains could be attributed to sp2 cross-linking among the small-size carbon sheets in the case of high-temperature carbonization. As for RSCHP2 and RSC700-P, compared with RSC and RSC700, the –O–C type oxygen peaks were once again emersion, which might be attributed to the existence of CO-P configuration in catalyst precursors with the introduction of P atoms. It is worth noting that the proportion of CO-P of RSCHP2 (0.22) was lower than RSC700-P (1.29), indicating that the highly introduced with P biomass carbon preparation via a common preparation procedure was more effectively obtained than hydrothermal phosphoric acid method. Although hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment temperature (180 °C) did not meet the requirement for P introducing, which usually requires 400–1000 °C, a small amount of the P atom was still introduced in the RSCHP2. In addition, the P2O5-type phosphorus peaks in RSC700-P were found due to the transformation of the residual phosphorus acid in the inner surface and/or outer surface of RSC700 into P2O5 in the case of high-temperature carbonization. However, a similar situation did not emerge in the RSCHP2, which was attributed to the fact that the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment was at a lower temperature than the formation of P2O5. These results suggested that hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment displayed poor results in introducing the P atom to biomass carbon. However, this method may play other roles for biomass carbon, such as reducing the size of graphite carbon sheets or increasing defects. This would be proved in the following characterization analysis. The bonding configuration and chemical composition of C, O, P, and S on all catalyst surfaces were analyzed by the XPS technique. As shown in Table 3, compared with catalyst precursors, the mass content of C 1 s in the RSCA, RSCA700, and RSCA-HP2 obviously decreased. In contrast, the proportion of O 1 s slightly increased, which is caused by the oxidation effect of sulfuric acid and the load of −SO3H groups. As for the phosphoric acid activation samples, it is noteworthy that the proportion of P 2p in the RSCA700-P had decreased remarkably, and the phosphorus species of RSCA-HP2 even disappeared completely. In addition, except for the RSCA700-P, the −SO3H groups of all the catalysts were found. These above results further confirmed the EDS mentioned above analysis results that P introducing was adverse for the sulfonation of biomass carbon. Graphite crystallite structure The overall structure of all the catalyst precursors was analyzed using an X-ray diffractometer technique (XRD). The X-ray diffraction patterns of RSC, RSC700, RSC700-P, and RSCHP2 are shown in Fig. 7 (a). XRD patterns of RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 exhibit a strong (002) and a weak (100) typical diffraction peak of graphite (2θ = 10°–30°, 35°–50°), whereas the (002) and (100) peak disappears completely in the RSC700-P [12]. These results mentioned above demonstrated that the RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 are composed of amorphous carbon of polycyclic aromatic carbon sheets arranged in a rather sizeable random manner. Furthermore, for the RSC700-P, the characteristic diffraction peaks belonging to P2O5 were found at 2θ values of 22.6°, 24.2°, 27.8°, 31.6°, 37.5°, and 42.9°, corresponding to the (110), (113), (201), (116), (207), and (303) planes, respectively [36]. This implied that a large number of P2O5 spread all over the external wall surface of RSC700-P. This result was confirmed by the XPS, SEM, and EDS characterization. Furthermore, the symmetry of 002 peaks in the catalyst precursors was relatively poor, particularly the RSC. This phenomenon indicated the presence of another band (γ) in the (002) band left-hand side. Generally, the γ peak relates to aliphatic side chains from the ring opening of glucose in cellulose, in which the strength of the peak was increased with the content of aliphatic side chains [12]. The above-mentioned view demonstrated that the RSC had more aliphatic side chains compared with the RSC700 and RSCHP2. The symmetry of 002 peaks in the RSC700 and RSCHP2 were relatively high, which was attributed to the fact that aliphatic side chains were removed. The aliphatic side chains of RSC700 were removed, which attributed to the pyrolysis of aliphatic side chains in the case of high-temperature carbonization [12]. Different from RSC700, the acting force of eliminated aliphatic side chains in the RSCHP2 was attributed to the etching effect of hydrothermal phosphoric acid. In addition, the (002) peak intensities of the three samples were in the order of RSC700>RSCHP2>RSC, which further proved that the corresponding samples contained alkyl side chains content in the order of RSC>RSCHP2>RSC700. The above results proved that the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment could efficiently remove aliphatic alkyl side chains in biomass carbon, consistent with the FT-IR results. The crystallite structure parameters of the RSC, RSC700, and RSCHP2 by quantitatively calculated were listed in Table 4 . In contrast, the information on crystallite structure parameters in RSC700-P was not obtained due to the P2O5 load on the external wall surface of RSC700-P to shield the signal of the structure parameter. As displayed in Table 4, compared RSC and RSC700, with the increase of carbonization temperature, the average stacking heights (Lc) and the interlayer spacing of crystallite structure (d002) of biomass carbon decrease, and the average lateral sizes (La) and the aromaticity (fa) of biomass carbon increases. These implied that graphite crystallite size in catalyst precursors became larger and sp2 hybrid carbons further increased, and the arrangement of aromatic carbon sheets was more orderly and compact in space with carbonization temperature rose. The above-mentioned results further demonstrated that the XPS characterization analysis result, which larger graphite crystallite size production from sp2 cross-linking among the small-size carbon sheets, was promoted under high-temperature carbonization. It is noteworthy that the La values of RSCHP2 (0.82) were lower than those of RSC (1.14) and RSC700 (2.00), suggesting a small graphite crystallite size in the RSCHP2. In addition, the (fa) values of RSCHP2 (0.72) were higher than RSC (0.62), which was prepared at the same carbonization temperature, implying that the RSCHP2 possessed more graphite crystallite. The above lattice parameters were obtained using the commonly used Scherrer method for calculation [37]. In order to verify more accurately the fact that the size of graphite crystallites in RSCA-HP2 obtained by preparation after hydrothermal phosphoric acid pretreatment decreases, compared to RSCA. Table 4 shows the La values for all samples obtained using the Williamson-Hall method. The La values obtained by the Williamson-Hall method were relatively high compared to those obtained by the Scherrer method. The above phenomenon is attributed to the fact that the peak width of the integration obtained during the calculation of the Williamson-Hall method introduces the broadening due to strain in the calculation in addition to the broadening due to crystallite size. For further details on the derivation of the Williamson-Hall method, one may refer to Text S3. Thus, the peak width of integration obtained by the Williamson-Hall method was higher than that obtained by the Scherrer method, which further leads to the large size of graphite crystallites obtained. These results confirmed that it contains more of the small-size graphite crystallite in the RSCHP2, which was obtained via hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment. Furthermore, the La values decrease of RSCHP2 indicates that the sp2 hybrid carbon of graphite crystallites framework in the biomass carbon could efficiently be etched via the hydrothermal phosphoric treatment. In other words, the aforementioned hydrothermal phosphoric treatment process might lead to large-size graphite crystallite framework division, further resulting in the large-size graphite crystallite conversion to the small-size graphite crystallite. It should be noted that the smaller size of graphite crystallite could supply available sp2 hybrid carbon edges, which may be beneficial for increasing the −SO3H group density of the catalyst. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to analyze the overall graphite crystallite structure of all catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the 002 peaks were more symmetrical than the catalyst precursor, and the γ peak of catalysts almost disappeared, especially the RSCA. It is worth noting that the technology of low-temperature sulfonation has two actions, which were the secondary carbonization and partial alkyl side chain fall-off for biomass carbon. Furthermore, the two actions may be caused by the strong oxidation and dehydration of concentrated H2SO4 [14]. Therefore, in the case of sulfonation reaction, this phenomenon could be attributed to the existence of secondary carbonization and partial alkyl side chain breakage in the RSC, resulting in the annular amorphous carbon ring opening and alkyl side chains decrease in the RSCA. These results mentioned above further lead to the γ peak of catalysts decrease. As shown in Table 4, the fa value of catalysts is universally higher than catalyst precursors, which further confirms the above-mentioned result. The La and fa of RSCA-HP2 were 0.75 and 0.77, according to Table 4, respectively. Compared with the RSCHP2, the La value of RSCA-HP2 was slightly decreased, and the fa value was slightly increased, which shows that the influence of low-temperature sulfonation treatment could be a little for the graphite crystallite structure of RSCHP2. Raman analysis According to the characteristics mentioned above, the main effect of the hydrothermal phosphoric acid craft was to decrease the size of graphite crystallite for biomass carbon, whereas there were no improved porosity structures. In addition, the hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment process could introduce a small amount of P atom to biomass carbon, according to the XPS analysis. However, the above-mentioned process of introducing the P atom was simultaneously followed by the production of lattice defect of graphite crystallite in biomass carbon. Therefore, further details about the defect types in the RSC, RSCHP2, RSCA, and RSCA-HP2 were analyzed using Raman spectra (Fig. 8 ). As shown in Fig. 8, Raman spectra show a typical d-band at ∼1370 cm−1, and G-band at ∼1600 cm−1 attributed to the lattice defects and the graphitic phase of sp2 hybridized C atoms in catalyst precursors (RSC and RSCHP2), respectively. In general, the peak area ratio size of the d-band and G-band indicated the density of defects in its framework, which were defined as ID/IG [38]. It is noteworthy that the defective structure in the graphite crystallite mainly originated from heteroatom doping, lattice deformation/deletion, and aliphatic alkyl side chain. As shown in Fig. 8, it was determined that the ID/IG values of the RSCHP2 (1.87) were higher than RSC (1.84), which indicates the fairly high density of defects/unordered domains in the RSCHP2 framework. According to the result of XPS analysis, for the RSCHP2, this might be attributed to the introduction of heteroatom, such as O/P atoms. In addition, the O/C atomic ratio of RSCHP2 was also higher than RSC, and P atoms were successfully introduced in the RSCHP2, which further confirmed the above-mentioned result. Secondly, according to the result of XRD, the average lateral sizes (La value) of graphite crystallite in the RSCHP2 were lower than RSC, implying that the lattice deformation/deletion existed in the RSCHP2. In view of the characteristics mentioned above, the highly unordered structure of RSCHP2 was due to the introduction of heteroatom and lattice defects. The above phenomena indicate that the introduction of P atoms efficiently increased the deformed or lattice defects of the RSCHP2. More defects in the RSCHP2 might further distort the carbon structure and provide more of the carbon sheet edges of providing sulfonic acid group loading. Compared with the catalyst precursors, the ID/IG values of RSCA showed a remarkable decrease and a slight decrease happened in the RSCA-HP2. This implied that the RSC possessed more alkyl side chain, which was etched sulphuric acid, compared with RSCHP2, which was consistent with the XRD results. It is noteworthy that the ID/IG values of RSCA-HP2 were still high (1.58), even if the precursors were processed with low-temperature sulfonation. Based on the aforementioned results of XPS, the signal peaks of P 2p in the RSCA-HP2 disappeared completely after low-temperature sulfonation, and the −SO3H groups were successfully introduced in the RSCA-HP2. In addition, the RSCHP2 had fewer aliphatic side chains, according to XRD results. Thus, it is reasonable to deduce that the high ID/IG values in the RSCA-HP2 were caused by deformed defects or lattice defects from unordered graphite crystallite and the load of −SO3H groups instead of the aliphatic alkyl side chain. Acid-base titration The acidity of RSCA, RSCA700, RSCA700-P, and RSCA-HP2 was determined by acid-base titration, and the results are shown in Table 5 . Combined with the functional group analysis of the catalyst by FT-IR and previous studies [13], it can be clear that the weak acid, medium strong acid, and strong acid sites of carbon-based catalysts correspond to −OH, −COOH, and −SO3H groups, respectively. Compared with other catalysts in this work, the total acidity and −SO3H density of RSCA-HP2 reached the maximum, which was 4.78 and 1.20 mmol/g, respectively. These phenomena mentioned above further confirmed the results of XPS, XRD, and Raman of characterization analysis that the small size graphite crystallite, deformed defects, or lattice defects in catalyst precursors were instrumental in providing more available sp2 hybrid carbon edges, which further increased the density of −SO3H groups in the carbon-base solid acid. Even compared with the total acidity (4.86 mmol/g) of commercially available macroporous sulfonic acid resins, the difference between RSCA-HP2 (4.78 mmol/g) was slight. Compared with RSCA and RSCA-HP2, the high-temperature as-prepared solid acid catalysts (RSCA-700) had a lower level of strong acid density owing to the large average lateral sizes of the graphitic phase. Moreover, Table S1 exhibits the total acidity and −SO3H density of biomass carbon-base solid acid catalysts reported in other literature. It could be seen that the obtained value of the total acidity and −SO3H density in this work was higher than the commonly reported results, indicating that RSCA-HP2 was expected to become a solid acid catalyst with high catalytic activity. Reaction mechanism Based on the adsorption experiment and DFT results, the possible catalytic mechanism of RSCA-HP2 catalytic hydration of α-pinene to α-terpineol was deduced. The α-pinene hydration to α-terpineol catalyzed by the RSCA-HP2 belongs to the heterogeneous catalytic reaction catalyzed by a solid catalyst, which took place near the active site of the catalyst (graphite crystallites framework). The graphite crystallite framework in the biomass carbon was greatly deformed to create defects in introducing the P atom. The defects in the graphite crystallites of RSCA-HP2 destroyed the big unlocalized π bond of the original graphite crystallite, resulting in the polarization of the P-orbital electron cloud of the big unlocalized π bond. In addition, α-pinene molecules were difficult to adsorb on graphite crystallites with intrinsic defects due to steric hindrance. Therefore, α-pinene molecules were "pushed" to the active site by the graphite crystallite framework under the two forces. Compared with the original graphite crystallite, α-pinene is more easily in contact with active sites due to defects in graphite crystallites. Secondly, the strong electronegative O atoms in the −SO3H group attracted the C=C of the pinene molecule. Subsequently, the protons from the −SO3H group implemented an electrophilic attack on the C=C of the α-pinene molecule. Excess proton was transferred to the vicinity of the quaternary carbon of α-pinene after α-pinene accepted the proton, breaking the bridge bond in α-pinene. The α-pinene molecules rearranged to form a tertiary carbon cation intermediate. Finally, the same tertiary carbocation may undergo a nucleophilic attack by water to produce α-terpineol. Notably, the -OH ions originated from water molecules and tended to attack the C=C of α-pinene molecules attributed to the O atom with strong electronegativity. The reason for the formation of a non-ring opening by-product is attributed to the fact that the C=C of α-pinene molecule was attacked by -OH ions before proton transfer to quaternary carbon. Except for small-size graphite crystallite and defects, the high selectivity of RSCA-HP2 for α-terpineol was also attributed to the high density −SO3H groups in the catalyst, providing more protons that could attack the C=C of α-pinene. In addition, excessive protons could further prevent -OH ions from rapidly attacking the C=C of α-pinene, thus promoting the further improvement of the selectivity of α-terpineol. Discussion In recent years, carbon-based materials have received particular attention due to their excellent electrical conductivity, large surface area, and chemical stability [44]. Common carbon-based types include activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, and graphene. It has been widely investigated that the porosity and surface functional groups of carbon-based materials have a significant impact on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Shaterian et al. developed a novel hydrogen storage material with multi-walled carbon nanotubes with a large specific surface area (∼ 2600 m2/g) as the support solidly loaded with SnFe2O4 [45]. The results showed that the hydrogen storage capacity of SnFe2O4@MWCNTS nanocomposites was higher than that of SnFe2O4 nanoparticles due to its larger surface. However, the vast majority of reports focusing only on the effects of porosity and surface functional groups on the properties of carbon-based materials are limited. In addition, other physicochemical properties of biomass carbon have yet to be explored. The source and cost of biomass carbon are more competitive than carbon nanotubes and graphene. It should be emphasized that biomass carbon was not a preferred support relative to the aforementioned carbon-based materials in terms of the complexity of biomass carbon composition. Based on this, the present study advocates focusing only on the physicochemical properties of the site hosting the acidic active sites (i.e., active Sp2-hybridized carbon graphite crystallites) while suppressing the increase in the porosity of biomass carbon in order to overcome the problem of the complexity of the biomass carbon composition that was difficult to analyze. Classical phosphoric acid impregnation of biomass was able to improve the porosity of carbon-based materials under high-temperature conditions. Therefore, a novel hydrothermal phosphoric acid pretreatment was used to suppress this factor of porosity enhancement and to modulate graphite crystallite size and defects in CACs. The correlation between −SO3H density, catalytic activity, graphite crystallites, and defects in CACs was systematically investigated. In addition, a combination of adsorption experiments and DTF was used for the first time to reveal the effects of graphite crystallite size and defects on the −SO3H density and hydration performance of CACs from the molecular orbital theory and electronic level. The results show that small-sized graphite crystallites and highly defective could effectively improve the −SO3H density and hydration catalytic performance in CACs. This work will provide theoretical and strong experimental evidence for the synergistic effect of graphite crystallite size and defects in biomass carbon. This synergistic effect has the potential to inform research in other fields, such as electrochemistry, biodiesel production, and hydrogen storage capacity. Conclusions In this work, a biomass carbon-based solid acid catalyst (RSCA-HP2) with high acidity, small-sized graphite crystallite, and high structural defects was prepared for the first time by hydrothermal phosphoric acid-low temperature sulfonation method. The characterization results show that the hydrothermal phosphoric acid technique could effectively modulate the size and structural defects of graphite crystallites in biomass carbon by etching hybridized carbon (sp2 and sp3) and P-atom doping mode. Compared to the conventional carbon-based solid acid catalyst (0.83 of La and 0.91 of ID/IG), the La value of RSCA-HP2 decreased to 0.75, and the ID/IG value increased to 1.58. The small size graphite crystallite and defects were instrumental in providing more available sp2 hybrid carbon edges, further increasing the density of −SO3H groups in the carbon-base solid acid. The −SO3H group density of the catalyst increased from 0.89 to 1.20 mmol/g after hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment. 87.06 % of α-pinene gave complete conversion with 55.38 % selectivity towards α-terpineol by as-synthesized RSCA-HP2 catalyst, which was higher than the reported data in the literature. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations show that the lattice defects of graphite crystallites in RSCA-HP2 lead to the polarization of the electron cloud around the catalyst, which further leads to the reduction of electrostatic resistance between α-pinene and the active catalytic sites. The DFT calculations were consistent with the thermodynamic experimental result. The apparent activation energy of hydration by the catalyst is 1.74 times lower than that of conventional biomass carbon-based solid acids. The size reduction of graphite crystallites could effectively reduce the α-terpineol adsorbed by the catalyst, which was considered a pivotal step in improving the selectivity of the α-terpineol. Moreover, high −SO3H density in the catalyst could provide a stable acid catalysis activity and retain its good reusability after three cycles (up to 66 h usage time). coredata.dc:description: This work, for the first time, highlights that small-sized graphite crystallite and highly defective carbon-based catalysts can effectively increase the −SO3H density of the catalysts and modulate the surface electronic properties of the catalysts, which further facilitates the α-pinene hydration reaction. Hydrothermal phosphoric acid modulation of graphite crystallite size and defects in carbon-based catalysts systematically revealed the correlation between −SO3H density, catalytic activity, graphite crystallite size, and defects in biomass carbon. The characterization results demonstrate that small-size graphite crystallites and high structural defects provide more sp2 hybridized carbon edges, contributing to the catalyst's increase of −SO3H density. The −SO3H group density of the catalyst increased from 0.89 to 1.20 mmol/g after hydrothermal phosphoric acid treatment. The catalyst has the highest efficiency in the α-pinene hydration to α-terpineol among the reported catalysts, in which 87.06 % of α-pinene was converted and reached a maximum α-terpineol selectivity (55.38 %) time only 22 h. Density functional theory calculations show that the lattice defects of graphite crystallites in catalysts lead to the polarization of the electron cloud around the catalyst, which further leads to the reduction of electrostatic resistance between α-pinene and the active catalytic sites. The apparent activation energy of hydration by the catalyst is 1.74 times lower than that of conventional biomass carbon-based solid acids. The reduction of graphite crystallite size is considered a critical step in improving the selectivity of α-terpineol attributed to the effective reduction of α-terpineol adsorbed on the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: A novel carbon-based solid acid catalyst with high acidity for the hydration of α-pinene to α-terpineol: Effect of graphite crystallite size and synergistic effect of defects
